content.$t:
selectedorderofappearance: -, paperid: spatialrugs, isaselectedpublication: 0, willappearinthetvslideshow: 0, year: 2020, authors: Buchmuller J., Schlegel U., Cakmak E., Keim D.A., and Dimara E., title: SpatialRugs: Enhancing Spatial Awareness of Movement in Dense Pixel Visualizations
, venue: EuroVis Workshop on Visual Analytics (EuroVA), extrapublicationinfo: Sweden, copycitation: J. F. Buchmüller, U. Schlegel, E. Cakmak, D. A. Keim, and E. Dimara, “SpatialRugs: Enhancing Spatial Awareness of Movement in Dense Pixel Visualizations,” in EuroVis Workshop on Visual Analytics, 2020., paperpdf: https://hal.archives-ouvertes.fr/hal-02972047/document, suppementarymaterial: https://bib.dbvis.de/uploadedFiles/SupplementalMaterialEuroVa.pdf, bibtex: @inproceedings{Buchmüller2020SpatialRugs,
abstract = {Compact visual summaries of spatio-temporal movement data often strive to express accurate positions of movers. We present SpatialRugs, a technique to enhance the spatial awareness of movements in dense pixel visualizations. SpatialRugs apply 2D colormaps to visualize location mapped to a juxtaposed display. We explore the effect of various colormaps discussing perceptual limitations and introduce a custom color-smoothing method to mitigate distorted patterns of collective movement behavior.},
author = {Buchmuller, Juri F and Schlegel, Udo and Cakmak, Eren, and Keim, Daniel A, and Dimara, Evanthia},
booktitle = {EuroVis Workshop on Visual Analytics (EuroVA)},
doi = {10.2312/eurova.20201078},
editor = {{Turkay, Cagatay and Vrotsou}, Katerina},
publisher = {The Eurographics Association},
title = {{SpatialRugs: Enhancing Spatial Awareness of Movement in Dense Pixel Visualizations}},
year = {2020}
}
, shortpreviewvideo: -, presentationslides: -, presentationvideo: https://youtu.be/M8dyindNhbA?t=361

gsx$authors.$t: Buchmuller J., Schlegel U., Cakmak E., Keim D.A., and Dimara E.

gsx$title.$t: SpatialRugs: Enhancing Spatial Awareness of Movement in Dense Pixel Visualizations

gsx$copycitation.$t: J. F. Buchmüller, U. Schlegel, E. Cakmak, D. A. Keim, and E. Dimara, “SpatialRugs: Enhancing Spatial Awareness of Movement in Dense Pixel Visualizations,” in EuroVis Workshop on Visual Analytics, 2020.

content.$t:
selectedorderofappearance: 1, paperid: interaction, isaselectedpublication: 1, willappearinthetvslideshow: 1, year: 2020, authors: Dimara E. and Perin C., title: What is Interaction for Data Visualization?, venue: IEEE Transactions on Visualization and Computer Graphics (TVCG / Proc. of Infovis '19), extrapublicationinfo: Vancouver, copycitation: E. Dimara and C. Perin, “What is Interaction for Data Visualization?,” IEEE Trans. Vis. Comput. Graph., vol. 26, no. 1, pp. 119–129, Jan. 2020., paperpdf: https://hal.archives-ouvertes.fr/hal-02197062/document, suppementarymaterial: https://osf.io/ej7xg/?view, bibtex: @article{Dimara2020Interaction,
abstract = {Interaction is fundamental to data visualization, but what "interaction" means in the context of visualization is ambiguous and confusing. We argue that this confusion is due to a lack of consensual definition. To tackle this problem, we start by synthesizing an inclusive view of interaction in the visualization community-including insights from information visualization, visual analytics and scientific visualization, as well as the input of both senior and junior visualization researchers. Once this view takes shape, we look at how interaction is defined in the field of human-computer interaction (HCI). By extracting commonalities and differences between the views of interaction in visualization and in HCI, we synthesize a definition of interaction for visualization. Our definition is meant to be a thinking tool and inspire novel and bolder interaction design practices. We hope that by better understanding what interaction in visualization is and what it can be, we will enrich the quality of interaction in visualization systems and empower those who use them.},
author = {Dimara, Evanthia and Perin, Charles},
doi = {10.1109/TVCG.2019.2934283},
issn = {1077-2626},
journal = {IEEE Transactions on Visualization and Computer Graphics},
month = {jan},
number = {1},
pages = {119--129},
title = {{What is Interaction for Data Visualization?}},
url = {https://hal.archives-ouvertes.fr/hal-02197062 https://ieeexplore.ieee.org/document/8805424/},
volume = {26},
year = {2020}
}
, shortpreviewvideo: https://vimeo.com/360445743, presentationslides: https://drive.google.com/file/d/1zREbLd_v8pI6N6tr4ZKF5C5LYfddvv22/view?usp=sharing, presentationvideo: https://vimeo.com/369712001

We argue that this confusion is due to a lack of consensual definition. To tackle this problem, we start by synthesizing an inclusive view of interaction in the visualization community-including insights from information visualization, visual analytics and scientific visualization, as well as the input of both senior and junior visualization researchers. Once this view takes shape, we look at how interaction is defined in the field of human-computer interaction (HCI). By extracting commonalities and differences between the views of interaction in visualization and in HCI, we synthesize a definition of interaction for visualization. Our definition is meant to be a thinking tool and inspire novel and bolder interaction design practices. We hope that by better understanding what interaction in visualization is and what it can be, we will enrich the quality of interaction in visualization systems and empower those who use them.},

content.$t:
selectedorderofappearance: -, paperid: retroactive, isaselectedpublication: 0, willappearinthetvslideshow: 1, year: 2020, authors: Raissi R., Dimara E., Berry J.H., Gray W.D., and Bailly G., title: Retroactive Transfer Phenomena in Alternating User Interfaces, venue: CHI Conference on Human Factors in Computing Systems, extrapublicationinfo: Honolulu, copycitation: R. Raissi, E. Dimara, J. H. Berry, W. D. Gray, and G. Bailly, “Retroactive Transfer Phenomena in Alternating User Interfaces,” in Proceedings of the 2020 CHI Conference on Human Factors in Computing Systems, 2020, pp. 1–14., paperpdf: https://hal.archives-ouvertes.fr/hal-02452719/document, suppementarymaterial: https://osf.io/yvdrx/?view_only=71fa4ad22ec64998afa63fcc9b4383b6, bibtex: @inproceedings{Raissi2020Retroactive,
abstract = {We investigated retroactive transfer when users alternate between different interfaces. Retroactive transfer is the influence of a newly learned interface on users' performance with a previously learned interface. In an interview study, participants described their experiences when alternating between different interfaces, e.g. different operating systems, devices or techniques. Negative retroactive transfer related to text entry was the most frequently reported incident. We then reported a laboratory experiment that investigated the impact of similarity between two abstract keyboard layouts, and the number of alternations between them, on retroactive interference. Results indicated that even small changes in the interference interface produced a significant performance drop for the entire previously learned interface. The amplitude of this performance drop decreases with the number of alternations. We suggest that retroactive transfer should receive more attention in HCI, as the ubiquitous nature of interactions across applications and systems requires users to increasingly alternate between similar interfaces.},
address = {New York, NY, USA},
author = {Raissi, Reyhaneh and Dimara, Evanthia and Berry, Jacquelyn H. and Gray, Wayne D. and Bailly, Gilles},
booktitle = {Proceedings of the 2020 CHI Conference on Human Factors in Computing Systems},
doi = {10.1145/3313831.3376538},
isbn = {9781450367080},
month = {apr},
pages = {1--14},
publisher = {ACM},
title = {{Retroactive Transfer Phenomena in Alternating User Interfaces}},
url = {https://dl.acm.org/doi/10.1145/3313831.3376538},
year = {2020}
}
, shortpreviewvideo: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5VpSQGMl9g8&feature=emb_logo&ab_channel=ACMSIGCHI, presentationslides: -, presentationvideo: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=29Sleaxx8K4&ab_channel=ReyhanehRAISSI

Negative retroactive transfer related to text entry was the most frequently reported incident. We then reported a laboratory experiment that investigated the impact of similarity between two abstract keyboard layouts, and the number of alternations between them, on retroactive interference. Results indicated that even small changes in the interference interface produced a significant performance drop for the entire previously learned interface. The amplitude of this performance drop decreases with the number of alternations. We suggest that retroactive transfer should receive more attention in HCI, as the ubiquitous nature of interactions across applications and systems requires users to increasingly alternate between similar interfaces.},

content.$t:
selectedorderofappearance: 2, paperid: taxonomy, isaselectedpublication: 1, willappearinthetvslideshow: 1, year: 2020, authors: Dimara E., Franconeri S., Plaisant C., Bezerianos A., and Dragicevic P., title: A Task-Based Taxonomy of Cognitive Biases for Information Visualization, venue: IEEE Transactions on Visualization and Computer Graphics (TVCG / Proc. of Infovis '19), extrapublicationinfo: Vancouver, copycitation: E. Dimara, S. Franconeri, C. Plaisant, A. Bezerianos, and P. Dragicevic, “A Task-Based Taxonomy of Cognitive Biases for Information Visualization,” IEEE Trans. Vis. Comput. Graph., vol. 26, no. 2, pp. 1413–1432, Feb. 2020., paperpdf: https://hal.sorbonne-universite.fr/hal-01868738/document, suppementarymaterial: https://hal.sorbonne-universite.fr/hal-01868738v2, bibtex: @article{Dimara2020Taxonomy,
abstract = {Information visualization designers strive to design data displays that allow for efficient exploration, analysis, and communication of patterns in data, leading to informed decisions. Unfortunately, human judgment and decision making are imperfect and often plagued by cognitive biases. There is limited empirical research documenting how these biases affect visual data analysis activities. Existing taxonomies are organized by cognitive theories that are hard to associate with visualization tasks. Based on a survey of the literature we propose a task-based taxonomy of 154 cognitive biases organized in 7 main categories. We hope the taxonomy will help visualization researchers relate their design to the corresponding possible biases, and lead to new research that detects and addresses biased judgment and decision making in data visualization.},
author = {Dimara, Evanthia and Franconeri, Steven and Plaisant, Catherine and Bezerianos, Anastasia and Dragicevic, Pierre},
doi = {10.1109/TVCG.2018.2872577},
issn = {1077-2626},
journal = {IEEE Transactions on Visualization and Computer Graphics},
keywords = {Index Terms-cognitive bias,classification,cognitive biases,decision making,taxonomy,visualization},
month = {feb},
number = {2},
pages = {1413--1432},
title = {{A Task-Based Taxonomy of Cognitive Biases for Information Visualization}},
url = {https://hal.sorbonne-universite.fr/hal-01868738 https://ieeexplore.ieee.org/document/8476234/},
volume = {26},
year = {2020}
}
, shortpreviewvideo: https://vimeo.com/364568413, presentationslides: https://drive.google.com/file/d/1V67EupbQUHZPI85Yi8uChBwihQ2oR1Ow/view?usp=sharing, presentationvideo: https://vimeo.com/373008296

@article{Dimara2020Taxonomy,
abstract = {Information visualization designers strive to design data displays that allow for efficient exploration, analysis, and communication of patterns in data, leading to informed decisions. There is limited empirical research documenting how these biases affect visual data analysis activities. Existing taxonomies are organized by cognitive theories that are hard to associate with visualization tasks. Based on a survey of the literature we propose a task-based taxonomy of 154 cognitive biases organized in 7 main categories. We hope the taxonomy will help visualization researchers relate their design to the corresponding possible biases, and lead to new research that detects and addresses biased judgment and decision making in data visualization.},

content.$t:
selectedorderofappearance: 3, paperid: mitigating, isaselectedpublication: 1, willappearinthetvslideshow: 1, year: 2019, authors: Dimara E., Bailly G., Bezerianos A., and Franconeri S., title: Mitigating the Attraction Effect with Visualizations, venue: IEEE Transactions on Visualization and Computer Graphics (TVCG / Proc. of Infovis '18), extrapublicationinfo: Berlin, copycitation: E. Dimara, G. Bailly, A. Bezerianos, and S. Franconeri, “Mitigating the Attraction Effect with Visualizations,” IEEE Trans. Vis. Comput. Graph., vol. 25, no. 1, pp. 850–860, Jan. 2019., paperpdf: https://hal.inria.fr/hal-01845004/document, suppementarymaterial: https://aviz.fr/deletion, bibtex: @article{Dimara2019Mitigating,
abstract = {Human decisions are prone to biases, and this is no less true for decisions made within data visualizations. Bias mitigation strategies often focus on the person, by educating people about their biases, typically with little success. We focus instead on the system, presenting the first evidence that altering the design of an interactive visualization tool can mitigate a strong bias-the attraction effect. Participants viewed 2D scatterplots where choices between superior alternatives were affected by the placement of other suboptimal points. We found that highlighting the superior alternatives weakened the bias, but did not eliminate it. We then tested an interactive approach where participants completely removed locally dominated points from the view, inspired by the elimination by aspects strategy in the decision-making literature. This approach strongly decreased the bias, leading to a counterintuitive suggestion: tools that allow removing inappropriately salient or distracting data from a view may help lead users to make more rational decisions.},
author = {Dimara, Evanthia and Bailly, Gilles and Bezerianos, Anastasia and Franconeri, Steven},
doi = {10.1109/TVCG.2018.2865233},
issn = {1077-2626},
journal = {IEEE Transactions on Visualization and Computer Graphics},
month = {jan},
number = {1},
pages = {850--860},
title = {{Mitigating the Attraction Effect with Visualizations}},
url = {https://ieeexplore.ieee.org/document/8440809/},
volume = {25},
year = {2019}
}
, shortpreviewvideo: https://vimeo.com/289784657, presentationslides: https://drive.google.com/file/d/1VqNX0wuCbnBWhnSmSR9lReeX9MnO6-2f/view?usp=sharing, presentationvideo: https://vimeo.com/300459670

@article{Dimara2019Mitigating,
abstract = {Human decisions are prone to biases, and this is no less true for decisions made within data visualizations. Bias mitigation strategies often focus on the person, by educating people about their biases, typically with little success. We focus instead on the system, presenting the first evidence that altering the design of an interactive visualization tool can mitigate a strong bias-the attraction effect. Participants viewed 2D scatterplots where choices between superior alternatives were affected by the placement of other suboptimal points. We found that highlighting the superior alternatives weakened the bias, but did not eliminate it. We then tested an interactive approach where participants completely removed locally dominated points from the view, inspired by the elimination by aspects strategy in the decision-making literature. This approach strongly decreased the bias, leading to a counterintuitive suggestion: tools that allow removing inappropriately salient or distracting data from a view may help lead users to make more rational decisions.},
author = {Dimara, Evanthia and Bailly, Gilles and Bezerianos, Anastasia and Franconeri, Steven},

content.$t:
selectedorderofappearance: 4, paperid: multidimensional, isaselectedpublication: 1, willappearinthetvslideshow: 1, year: 2018, authors: Dimara E., Bezerianos A., and Dragicevic P. , title: Conceptual and Methodological Issues in Evaluating Multidimensional Visualizations for Decision Support, venue: IEEE Transactions on Visualization and Computer Graphics (TVCG / Proc. of Infovis '17), extrapublicationinfo: Phoenix, copycitation: E. Dimara, A. Bezerianos, and P. Dragicevic, “Conceptual and Methodological Issues in Evaluating Multidimensional Visualizations for Decision Support,” IEEE Trans. Vis. Comput. Graph., vol. 24, no. 1, pp. 749–759, Jan. 2018., paperpdf: https://hal.inria.fr/hal-01584729/document, suppementarymaterial: https://aviz.fr/dm, bibtex: @article{Dimara2018DecisionSupport,
abstract = {We explore how to rigorously evaluate multidimensional visualizations for their ability to support decision making. We first define multi-attribute choice tasks, a type of decision task commonly performed with such visualizations. We then identify which of the existing multidimensional visualizations are compatible with such tasks, and set out to evaluate three elementary visualizations: parallel coordinates, scatterplot matrices and tabular visualizations. Our method consists in first giving participants low-level analytic tasks, in order to ensure that they properly understood the visualizations and their interactions. Participants are then given multi-attribute choice tasks consisting of choosing holiday packages. We assess decision support through multiple objective and subjective metrics, including a decision accuracy metric based on the consistency between the choice made and self-reported preferences for attributes. We found the three visualizations to be comparable on most metrics, with a slight advantage for tabular visualizations. In particular, tabular visualizations allow participants to reach decisions faster. Thus, although decision time is typically not central in assessing decision support, it can be used as a tie-breaker when visualizations achieve similar decision accuracy. Our results also suggest that indirect methods for assessing choice confidence may allow to better distinguish between visualizations than direct ones. We finally discuss the limitations of our methods and directions for future work, such as the need for more sensitive metrics of decision support.},
author = {Dimara, Evanthia and Bezerianos, Anastasia and Dragicevic, Pierre},
doi = {10.1109/TVCG.2017.2745138},
isbn = {1077-2626 VO - PP},
issn = {1077-2626},
journal = {IEEE Transactions on Visualization and Computer Graphics},
month = {jan},
number = {1},
pages = {749--759},
publisher = {IEEE},
title = {{Conceptual and Methodological Issues in Evaluating Multidimensional Visualizations for Decision Support}},
url = {https://hal.inria.fr/hal-01584729/document http://ieeexplore.ieee.org/document/8019855/},
volume = {24},
year = {2018}
}
, shortpreviewvideo: https://vimeo.com/230840695, presentationslides: https://drive.google.com/file/d/0B9ho1_WydCR9QXRmR2hKZmF1ejA/view?usp=sharing, presentationvideo: https://vimeo.com/238501814

gsx$bibtex.$t:
@article{Dimara2018DecisionSupport,
abstract = {We explore how to rigorously evaluate multidimensional visualizations for their ability to support decision making. We first define multi-attribute choice tasks, a type of decision task commonly performed with such visualizations. We then identify which of the existing multidimensional visualizations are compatible with such tasks, and set out to evaluate three elementary visualizations: parallel coordinates, scatterplot matrices and tabular visualizations. Our method consists in first giving participants low-level analytic tasks, in order to ensure that they properly understood the visualizations and their interactions. Participants are then given multi-attribute choice tasks consisting of choosing holiday packages. We assess decision support through multiple objective and subjective metrics, including a decision accuracy metric based on the consistency between the choice made and self-reported preferences for attributes. We found the three visualizations to be comparable on most metrics, with a slight advantage for tabular visualizations. In particular, tabular visualizations allow participants to reach decisions faster. Thus, although decision time is typically not central in assessing decision support, it can be used as a tie-breaker when visualizations achieve similar decision accuracy. Our results also suggest that indirect methods for assessing choice confidence may allow to better distinguish between visualizations than direct ones. We finally discuss the limitations of our methods and directions for future work, such as the need for more sensitive metrics of decision support.},
author = {Dimara, Evanthia and Bezerianos, Anastasia and Dragicevic, Pierre},
doi = {10.1109/TVCG.2017.2745138},
isbn = {1077-2626 VO - PP},
issn = {1077-2626},

month = {jan},

title = {{Conceptual and Methodological Issues in Evaluating Multidimensional Visualizations for Decision Support}},

content.$t:
selectedorderofappearance: -, paperid: thesis, isaselectedpublication: 0, willappearinthetvslideshow: 1, year: 2017, authors: Dimara E., title: Information Visualization for Decision Making : Identifying Biases and Moving Beyond the Visual Analysis Paradigm, venue: University Paris Saclay, extrapublicationinfo: Paris, copycitation: E. Dimara, “Information Visualization for Decision Making : Identifying Biases and Moving Beyond the Visual Analysis Paradigm,” University Paris Saclay, 2017., paperpdf: https://tel.archives-ouvertes.fr/tel-01968033v2/document, suppementarymaterial: https://www.theses.fr/2017SACLS367, bibtex: @phdthesis{Dimara2017DecisionMaking,
abstract = {There are problems neither humans nor computers can solve alone. Computer-supported visu- alizations are a well-known solution when humans need to reason based on a large amount of data. The more effective a visualization, the more complex the problems that can be solved. In information visualization research, to be considered effective, a visualization typically needs to support data comprehension. Evaluation methods focus on whether users indeed understand the displayed data, can gain insights and are able to perform a set of analytic tasks, e.g., to identify if two variables are correlated. This dissertation suggests moving beyond this "visual analysis paradigm" by extending research focus to another type of task: decision making. Decision tasks are essential to everybody, from the manager of a company who needs to routinely make risky decisions to an ordinary person who wants to choose a career life path or simply find a camera to buy. Yet decisions do not merely involve information understanding and are difficult to study. Decision tasks can involve subjective preferences, do not always have a clear ground truth, and they often depend on external knowledge which may not be part of the displayed dataset. Nevertheless, decision tasks are neither part of visualization task taxonomies nor formally defined. Moreover, visualization research lacks metrics, methodologies and empirical works that validate the effectiveness of visualizations in supporting a decision. This dissertation provides an operational definition for a particular class of decision tasks and reports a systematic analysis to investigate the extent to which existing multidimensional visualizations are compatible with such tasks. It further reports on the first empirical comparison of multidimensional visualizations for their ability to support decisions and outlines a methodology and metrics to assess decision accuracy. It further explores the role of instructions in both decision tasks and equivalent analytic tasks, and identifies differences in accuracy between those tasks. Similarly to vision science that informs visualization researchers and practitioners on the limita- tions of human vision, moving beyond the visual analysis paradigm would mean acknowledging the limitations of human reasoning. This dissertation reviews decision theory to understand how humans should, could and do make decisions and formulates a new taxonomy of cognitive biases based on the user task where such biases occur. It further empirically shows that cognitive biases can be present even when information is well-visualized, and that a decision can be “correct” yet irrational, in the sense that people's decisions are influenced by irrelevant information. This dissertation finally examines how biases can be alleviated. Current methods for improving human reasoning often involve extensive training on abstract principles and procedures that often appear ineffective. Yet visualizations have an ace up their sleeve: visualization designers can re-design the environment to alter the way people process the data. This dissertation revisits decision theory to identify possible design solutions. It further empirically demonstrates that enriching a visualization with interactions that facilitate alternative decision strategies can yield more rational decisions. Through empirical studies, this dissertation suggests that the visual analysis paradigm cannot fully address the challenges of visualization-supported decision making, but that moving beyond can contribute to making visualization a powerful decision support tool.},
author = {Dimara, Evanthia},
pages = {1--234},
school = {University Paris Saclay},
title = {{Information Visualization for Decision Making : Identifying Biases and Moving Beyond the Visual Analysis Paradigm}},
url = {https://tel.archives-ouvertes.fr/tel-01968033v2},
year = {2017}
}
, shortpreviewvideo: -, presentationslides: -, presentationvideo: -

gsx$title.$t: Information Visualization for Decision Making : Identifying Biases and Moving Beyond the Visual Analysis Paradigm

gsx$copycitation.$t: E. Dimara, “Information Visualization for Decision Making : Identifying Biases and Moving Beyond the Visual Analysis Paradigm,” University Paris Saclay, 2017.

content.$t:
selectedorderofappearance: -, paperid: dcpairs, isaselectedpublication: 0, willappearinthetvslideshow: 0, year: 2017, authors: Dimara E., Valdivia P., and Kinkeldey C., title: DcPAIRS: A Pairs Plot Based Decision Support System, venue: EuroVis Posters 2017, extrapublicationinfo: Barcelona, copycitation: E. Dimara, P. Valdivia, and C. Kinkeldey, “DCPAIRS: A Pairs Plot Based Decision Support System,” in EuroVis-19th EG/VGTC Conference on Visualization, 2017., paperpdf: https://hal.inria.fr/hal-01516470/document, suppementarymaterial: https://hal.inria.fr/hal-01516470/, bibtex: @inproceedings{Dimara2017DcPairs,
abstract = {Visualizations designed to support multi-attribute decisions often use colors to encode the identity of the attributes. This ap- proach facilitates mapping of attributes across multiple coordinated views but it has certain limitations: colors often commu- nicate semantics (e.g., red stands for “danger”) deemed to influence the user's preference, and qualitative color palettes are of limited scalability. We are currently developing a tool with an alternative approach, DCPAIRS: a pairs plot based decision making support tool that employs a compact overview of the decision space and uses visual encodings that communicate un- certainty and suboptimal preference elicitation. Instead of encoding the identity of attributes we use colors for user-authored annotations to support the decision making process. A use case scenario of a prospective undergraduate student choosing a university from the “QS world university ranking” dataset illustrates the functionality ofthe tool.},
author = {Dimara, Evanthia and Valdivia, Paola and Kinkeldey, Christoph},
booktitle = {EuroVis},
title = {{DCPAIRS: A Pairs Plot Based Decision Support System}},
year = {2017}
}
, shortpreviewvideo: -, presentationslides: -, presentationvideo: -

gsx$authors.$t: Dimara E., Valdivia P., and Kinkeldey C.

gsx$title.$t: DcPAIRS: A Pairs Plot Based Decision Support System

gsx$copycitation.$t: E. Dimara, P. Valdivia, and C. Kinkeldey, “DCPAIRS: A Pairs Plot Based Decision Support System,” in EuroVis-19th EG/VGTC Conference on Visualization, 2017.

content.$t:
selectedorderofappearance: -, paperid: narratives, isaselectedpublication: 0, willappearinthetvslideshow: 1, year: 2017, authors: Dimara E., Bezerianos A., and Dragicevic P. , title: Narratives in Crowdsourced Evaluation of Visualizations: A Double-Edged Sword?, venue: CHI Conference on Human Factors in Computing Systems, extrapublicationinfo: Denver, copycitation: E. Dimara, A. Bezerianos, and P. Dragicevic, “Narratives in Crowdsourced Evaluation of Visualizations: A Double-Edged Sword?,” in Proceedings of the 2017 CHI Conference on Human Factors in Computing Systems, 2017, pp. 5475–5484., paperpdf: https://hal.inria.fr/hal-01448095/document, suppementarymaterial: https://aviz.fr/narratives, bibtex: @inproceedings{Dimara2017Narratives,
abstract = {We explore the effects of providing task context when evaluat- ing visualization tools using crowdsourcing. We gave crowd- workers i) abstract information visualization tasks without any context, ii) tasks where we added semantics to the dataset, and iii) tasks with two types of backstory narratives: an analytic narrative and a decision-making narrative. Contrary to our expectations, we did not find evidence that adding data semantics increases accuracy, and further found that our backstory narr tives can even decrease accuracy. Adding dataset semantics can however increase attention and provide subjective benefits in terms of confidence, perceived easiness, task enjoyability and perceived usefulness of the visualization. Nevertheless, our backstory narratives did not appear to provide additional subjective benefits. These preliminary findings suggest that narratives may have complex and unanticipated effects, calling for more studies in this area. ACM},
address = {New York, NY, USA},
author = {Dimara, Evanthia and Bezerianos, Anastasia and Dragicevic, Pierre},
booktitle = {Proceedings of the 2017 CHI Conference on Human Factors in Computing Systems},
doi = {10.1145/3025453.3025870},
isbn = {9781450346559},
month = {may},
pages = {5475--5484},
publisher = {ACM},
title = {{Narratives in Crowdsourced Evaluation of Visualizations: A Double-Edged Sword?}},
url = {http://dl.acm.org/citation.cfm?doid=3025453.3025870 https://dl.acm.org/doi/10.1145/3025453.3025870},
year = {2017}
}, shortpreviewvideo: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BzRh1yM-Lxo&ab_channel=ACMSIGCHI, presentationslides: https://drive.google.com/file/d/0B9ho1_WydCR9Z1RHb2xGTGZoRVE/view?usp=sharing, presentationvideo: -

We gave crowd- workers i) abstract information visualization tasks without any context, ii) tasks where we added semantics to the dataset, and iii) tasks with two types of backstory narratives: an analytic narrative and a decision-making narrative. Contrary to our expectations, we did not find evidence that adding data semantics increases accuracy, and further found that our backstory narr tives can even decrease accuracy. Adding dataset semantics can however increase attention and provide subjective benefits in terms of confidence, perceived easiness, task enjoyability and perceived usefulness of the visualization. Nevertheless, our backstory narratives did not appear to provide additional subjective benefits. These preliminary findings suggest that narratives may have complex and unanticipated effects, calling for more studies in this area. ACM},

content.$t:
selectedorderofappearance: 5, paperid: attraction, isaselectedpublication: 1, willappearinthetvslideshow: 1, year: 2017, authors: Dimara E., Bezerianos A., and Dragicevic P. , title: [Best Paper Honorable Mention] The Attraction Effect in Information Visualization, venue: IEEE Transactions on Visualization and Computer Graphics (TVCG / Proc. of Infovis '16), extrapublicationinfo: Baltimore, copycitation: E. Dimara, A. Bezerianos, and P. Dragicevic, “The Attraction Effect in Information Visualization,” IEEE Trans. Vis. Comput. Graph., vol. 23, no. 1, pp. 471–480, Jan. 2017., paperpdf: https://hal.inria.fr/hal-01355750/document, suppementarymaterial: https://aviz.fr/decoy, bibtex: @article{Dimara2017AttractionEffect,
abstract = {{ The attraction effect is a well-studied cognitive bias in decision making research, where one's choice between two alternatives is influenced by the presence of an irrelevant (dominated) third alternative. We examine whether this cognitive bias, so far only tested with three alternatives and simple presentation formats such as numerical tables, text and pictures, also appears in visualizations. Since visualizations can be used to support decision making - e.g., when choosing a house to buy or an employee to hire - a systematic bias could have important implications. In a first crowdsource experiment, we indeed partially replicated the attraction effect with three alternatives presented as a numerical table, and observed similar effects when they were presented as a scatterplot. In a second experiment, we investigated if the effect extends to larger sets of alternatives, where the number of alternatives is too large for numerical tables to be practical. Our findings indicate that the bias persists for larger sets of alternatives presented as scatterplots. We discuss implications for future research on how to further study and possibly alleviate the attraction effect.},
author = {Dimara, Evanthia and Bezerianos, Anastasia and Dragicevic, Pierre},
doi = {10.1109/TVCG.2016.2598594},
isbn = {1077-2626},
issn = {1077-2626},
journal = {IEEE Transactions on Visualization and Computer Graphics},
month = {jan},
number = {1},
pages = {471--480},
publisher = {IEEE},
title = {{The Attraction Effect in Information Visualization}},
url = {http://ieeexplore.ieee.org/document/7539348/},
volume = {23},
year = {2017}
}
, shortpreviewvideo: https://vimeo.com/182971122, presentationslides: https://drive.google.com/file/d/1A5pp3kD5OKAFePpaygq4sWevLAJqSS8d/view?usp=sharing, presentationvideo: https://vimeo.com/226491954

gsx$bibtex.$t:
@article{Dimara2017AttractionEffect,
abstract = {{ The attraction effect is a well-studied cognitive bias in decision making research, where one's choice between two alternatives is influenced by the presence of an irrelevant (dominated) third alternative. We examine whether this cognitive bias, so far only tested with three alternatives and simple presentation formats such as numerical tables, text and pictures, also appears in visualizations. Since visualizations can be used to support decision making - e.g., when choosing a house to buy or an employee to hire - a systematic bias could have important implications. In a first crowdsource experiment, we indeed partially replicated the attraction effect with three alternatives presented as a numerical table, and observed similar effects when they were presented as a scatterplot. In a second experiment, we investigated if the effect extends to larger sets of alternatives, where the number of alternatives is too large for numerical tables to be practical. Our findings indicate that the bias persists for larger sets of alternatives presented as scatterplots. We discuss implications for future research on how to further study and possibly alleviate the attraction effect.},
author = {Dimara, Evanthia and Bezerianos, Anastasia and Dragicevic, Pierre},
doi = {10.1109/TVCG.2016.2598594},
isbn = {1077-2626},

content.$t:
selectedorderofappearance: -, paperid: testing, isaselectedpublication: 0, willappearinthetvslideshow: 0, year: 2016, authors: Dimara E., Bezerianos A., and Dragicevic P. , title: Testing the Attraction Effect on Two Information Visualization Datasets, venue: [Research Report] RR-8895, Inria Saclay , extrapublicationinfo: Ile de France, copycitation: E. Dimara, A. Bezerianos, and P. Dragicevic, “Testing the Attraction Effect on Two Information Visualization Datasets,” Mar. 2016., paperpdf: https://hal.inria.fr/hal-01295624/document, bibtex: @techreport{Dimara2016Testing,
abstract = {The attraction effect is a well-studied cognitive bias in decision making research, where people's choice between two options is influenced by the presence of an irrelevant (dominated) third option. In another article, we report on two crowdsourced experiments showing compelling evidence that the attraction effect can generalize to visualizations. However, we also conducted another experiment between the two where we failed to observe an effect. This experiment used scatterplots generated from real datasets, and restricted participants' choice between exactly two alternatives. In accordance with the principle of full reporting, we report on this experiment and discuss the possible reasons for this negative result.},
author = {Dimara, Evanthia and Bezerianos, Anastasia and Dragicevic, Pierre},
institution = {Inria},
month = {mar},
number = {RR-8895},
pages = {14},
title = {{Testing the Attraction Effect on Two Information Visualization Datasets}},
type = {Research Report},
url = {http://hal.inria.fr/hal-01295624},
year = {2016}
}
, shortpreviewvideo: -, presentationslides: -, presentationvideo: -

In another article, we report on two crowdsourced experiments showing compelling evidence that the attraction effect can generalize to visualizations. However, we also conducted another experiment between the two where we failed to observe an effect. This experiment used scatterplots generated from real datasets, and restricted participants' choice between exactly two alternatives. In accordance with the principle of full reporting, we report on this experiment and discuss the possible reasons for this negative result.},

content.$t:
selectedorderofappearance: -, paperid: historical, isaselectedpublication: 0, willappearinthetvslideshow: 0, year: 2015, authors: Boukhelifa N., Giannisakis E., Dimara E., Willett W., and Fekete J-D. , title: Supporting Historical Research through User-centered Visual Analytics, venue: EuroVis Workshop on Visual Analytics (EuroVA), extrapublicationinfo: Sardinia, copycitation: Boukhelifa N., Giannisakis E., Dimara E., Willett W., and Fekete J-D., “Supporting Historical Research Through User-Centered Visual Analytics,” in EuroVis Workshop on Visual Analytics (EuroVA), 2015., paperpdf: https://hal.inria.fr/hal-01156527/document, suppementarymaterial: https://www.aviz.fr/Research/CENDARI, bibtex: @inproceedings{Boukhelifa2015Historical,
abstract = {In this paper we describe the development and evaluation of a visual analytics tool to support historical research. Historians continuously gather data related to their scholarly research from archival visits and background search. Organising and making sense of all this data can be challenging as many historians continue to rely on analog or basic digital tools. We built an integrated note-taking environment for historians which unifies a set of func-tionalities we identified as important for historical research including editing, tagging, searching, sharing and visualization. Our approach was to involve users from the initial stage of brainstorming and requirement analysis through to design, implementation and evaluation. We report on the process and results of our work, and conclude by reflecting on our own experience in conducting user-centered visual analytics design for digital humanities.},
author = {Boukhelifa, Nadia and Giannisakis, Emmanouil and Dimara, Evanthia and Willett, Wesley and Fekete, Jean-Daniel and Bertini, E and Roberts, J C},
booktitle = {EuroVis Workshop on Visual Analytics (EuroVA)},
doi = {10.2312/eurova.20151095},
editor = {Roberts, E. Bertini and J. C.},
publisher = {The Eurographics Association},
title = {{Supporting Historical Research Through User-Centered Visual Analytics}},
url = {https://hal.inria.fr/hal-01156527},
year = {2015}
}
, shortpreviewvideo: -, presentationslides: -, presentationvideo: -

@inproceedings{Boukhelifa2015Historical,
abstract = {In this paper we describe the development and evaluation of a visual analytics tool to support historical research. Historians continuously gather data related to their scholarly research from archival visits and background search. Organising and making sense of all this data can be challenging as many historians continue to rely on analog or basic digital tools. We built an integrated note-taking environment for historians which unifies a set of func-tionalities we identified as important for historical research including editing, tagging, searching, sharing and visualization. Our approach was to involve users from the initial stage of brainstorming and requirement analysis through to design, implementation and evaluation. We report on the process and results of our work, and conclude by reflecting on our own experience in conducting user-centered visual analytics design for digital humanities.},
author = {Boukhelifa, Nadia and Giannisakis, Emmanouil and Dimara, Evanthia and Willett, Wesley and Fekete, Jean-Daniel and Bertini, E and Roberts, J C},
booktitle = {EuroVis Workshop on Visual Analytics (EuroVA)},

year = {2015}
}

content.$t:
selectedorderofappearance: -, paperid: immersive, isaselectedpublication: 0, willappearinthetvslideshow: 0, year: 2014, authors: Chapoulie E., Marchal M., Dimara E., Roussou M., Lombardo J-C., and Drettakis G., title: Evaluation of Direct Manipulation using Finger Tracking for Complex Tasks in an Immersive Cube, venue: Virtual Reality, extrapublicationinfo: -, copycitation: E. Chapoulie, M. Marchal, E. Dimara, M. Roussou, J.-C. Lombardo, and G. Drettakis, “Evaluation of direct manipulation using finger tracking for complex tasks in an immersive cube,” Virtual Real., vol. 18, no. 3, pp. 203–217, Sep. 2014., paperpdf: https://hal.inria.fr/file/index/docid/1060303/filename/gesturesCaveBasilic.pdf, suppementarymaterial: http://www-sop.inria.fr/reves/Basilic/2014/CMDRLD14/, bibtex: @article{Chapoulie2014Immersive,
abstract = {A solution for interaction using finger tracking in a cubic immersive virtual reality system (or immersive cube) is presented. Rather than using a traditional wand device, users can manipulate objects with fingers of both hands in a close-to-natural manner for moderately complex, general purpose tasks. Our solution couples finger tracking with a real-time physics engine, combined with a heuristic approach for hand manipulation, which is robust to tracker noise and simulation instabilities. A first study has been performed to evaluate our interface, with tasks involving complex manipulations, such as balancing objects while walking in the cube. The user's finger-tracked manipulation was compared to manipulation with a 6 degree-of-freedom wand (or flystick), as well as with carrying out the same task in the real world. Users were also asked to perform a free task, allowing us to observe their perceived level of presence in the scene. Our results show that our approach provides a feasible interface for immersive cube environments and is perceived by users as being closer to the real experience compared to the wand. However, the wand outperforms direct manipulation in terms of speed and precision. We conclude with a discussion of the results and implications for further research. {\textcopyright} 2014 Springer-Verlag London.},
author = {Chapoulie, Emmanuelle and Marchal, Maud and Dimara, Evanthia and Roussou, Maria and Lombardo, Jean-Christophe and Drettakis, George},
doi = {10.1007/s10055-014-0246-0},
issn = {1359-4338},
journal = {Virtual Reality},
keywords = {Direct manipulation,Finger tracking,Immersive cube,Virtual reality},
month = {sep},
number = {3},
pages = {203--217},
title = {{Evaluation of direct manipulation using finger tracking for complex tasks in an immersive cube}},
url = {http://link.springer.com/10.1007/s10055-014-0246-0},
volume = {18},
year = {2014}
}
, shortpreviewvideo: https://vimeo.com/89529971, presentationslides: -, presentationvideo: -

gsx$bibtex.$t:
@article{Chapoulie2014Immersive,
abstract = {A solution for interaction using finger tracking in a cubic immersive virtual reality system (or immersive cube) is presented. Rather than using a traditional wand device, users can manipulate objects with fingers of both hands in a close-to-natural manner for moderately complex, general purpose tasks. Our solution couples finger tracking with a real-time physics engine, combined with a heuristic approach for hand manipulation, which is robust to tracker noise and simulation instabilities. A first study has been performed to evaluate our interface, with tasks involving complex manipulations, such as balancing objects while walking in the cube. The user's finger-tracked manipulation was compared to manipulation with a 6 degree-of-freedom wand (or flystick), as well as with carrying out the same task in the real world. Users were also asked to perform a free task, allowing us to observe their perceived level of presence in the scene. Our results show that our approach provides a feasible interface for immersive cube environments and is perceived by users as being closer to the real experience compared to the wand. However, the wand outperforms direct manipulation in terms of speed and precision. We conclude with a discussion of the results and implications for further research. {\textcopyright} 2014 Springer-Verlag London.},
author = {Chapoulie, Emmanuelle and Marchal, Maud and Dimara, Evanthia and Roussou, Maria and Lombardo, Jean-Christophe and Drettakis, George},
doi = {10.1007/s10055-014-0246-0},

content.$t:
selectedorderofappearance: -, paperid: availability, isaselectedpublication: 0, willappearinthetvslideshow: 0, year: 2014, authors: Dimara E., Dragicevic P., and Bezerianos A., title: Accounting for Availability Biases in Information Visualization, venue: IEEE VIS DECISIVe: Workshop on Dealing with Cognitive Biases in Visualizations , extrapublicationinfo: Paris, copycitation: E. Dimara, P. Dragicevic, and A. Bezerianos, “Accounting for Availability Biases in Information Visualization,” in IEEE VIS 2014 DECISIVe: Workshop on Dealing with Cognitive Biases in Visualizations., 2014., paperpdf: https://hal.inria.fr/hal-01377996/document, suppementarymaterial: https://hal.inria.fr/hal-01377996, bibtex: @inproceedings{Dimara2014Availability,
abstract = {The availability heuristic is a strategy that people use to make quick decisions but often lead to systematic errors. We propose three ways that visualization could facilitate unbiased decision- making. First, visualizations can alter the way our memory stores the events for later recall, so as to improve users' long-term intuitions. Second, the known biases could lead to new visualization guidelines. Third, we suggest the design of decision- making tools that are inspired by heuristics, e.g. suggesting intuitive approximations, rather than target to present exhaustive comparisons of all possible outcomes, or automated solutions for choosing decisions.},
author = {Dimara, Evanthia and Dragicevic, Pierre and Bezerianos, Anastasia},
booktitle = {IEEE VIS 2014 DECISIVe: Workshop on Dealing with Cognitive Biases in Visualizations.},
title = {{Accounting for Availability Biases in Information Visualization}},
year = {2014}
}
, shortpreviewvideo: -, presentationslides: https://drive.google.com/file/d/12jINiL_FJSUESrOYaYQdy7i2_b4e3-Ha/view?usp=sharing, presentationvideo: -

gsx$authors.$t: Dimara E., Dragicevic P., and Bezerianos A.

gsx$title.$t: Accounting for Availability Biases in Information Visualization

gsx$venue.$t: IEEE VIS DECISIVe: Workshop on Dealing with Cognitive Biases in Visualizations

gsx$copycitation.$t: E. Dimara, P. Dragicevic, and A. Bezerianos, “Accounting for Availability Biases in Information Visualization,” in IEEE VIS 2014 DECISIVe: Workshop on Dealing with Cognitive Biases in Visualizations., 2014.

content.$t:
selectedorderofappearance: -, paperid: storyteller, isaselectedpublication: 0, willappearinthetvslideshow: 0, year: 2012, authors: Bae B.C., Brunete A., Malik U., Dimara E., Jermsurawong J.,  and Mavridis N., title: Towards an Empathizing and Adaptive Storyteller System, venue: AAAI Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Interactive Digital Entertainment, extrapublicationinfo: Stanford, copycitation: B.-C. Bae, A. Brunete, U. Malik, E. Dimara, J. Jermsurawong, and N. Mavridis, “Towards an empathizing and adaptive storyteller system,” in AAAI Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Interactive Digital Entertainment, 2012., paperpdf: https://core.ac.uk/download/pdf/50527269.pdf, suppementarymaterial: -, bibtex: @inproceedings{Bae2012Empathising,
abstract = {This paper describes our ongoing effort to build an empathizing and adaptive storyteller system. The system under development aims to utilize emotional expressions generated from an avatar or a humanoid robot in addition to the listener's responses which are monitored in real time, in order to deliver a story in an effective manner. We conducted a pilot study and the results were analyzed in two ways: first, through a survey questionnaire analysis based on the participant's subjective ratings; second, through automated video analysis based on the participant's emotional facial expression and eye blinking. The survey questionnaire results show that male participants have a tendency of more empathizing with a story character when a virtual storyteller is present, as compared to audio-only narration. The video analysis results show that the number of eye blinking of the participants is thought to be reciprocal to their attention. Copyright {\textcopyright} 2012, Association for the Advancement of Artificial Intelligence. All rights reserved.},
author = {Bae, B.-C. and Brunete, A. and Malik, U. and Dimara, E. and Jermsurawong, J. and Mavridis, N.},
booktitle = {AAAI Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Interactive Digital Entertainment},
isbn = {9781577355854},
title = {{Towards an empathizing and adaptive storyteller system}},
year = {2012}
}
